values.Description: We strive to bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and real-world action. By encouraging the application of insights gained through dialogue, we aim to catalyze positive change in individuals and communities.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We recognize that meaningful discussions incorporate various elements: scientific evidence, emotional intelligence, spiritual insights, and personal experiences. This multifaceted approach leads to richer, more nuanced understanding.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We make complex philosophical ideas relevant and understandable. By connecting abstract concepts to contemporary issues, we empower individuals to engage more deeply with the world around them.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We champion the power of respectful, open communication to bridge divides and view conflict as an opportunity for deeper understanding. By teaching the art of productive disagreement, we turn potential friction into a catalyst for creative problem-solving.. By facilitating conversations that embrace diverse viewpoints, we work towards mutual understanding and societal progress.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: As an Presenter, if someone doesn’t understand what you’re saying, it’s your responsibility to make sure that they do; they are not dense. Figure out a way to help them understand. That’s your responsibility.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: Everything is either a Note or a Task
values.Description:
Tasks
A Task is any specific deed that that will be accomplished. 
All Tasks should be entered, assigned, categorized, and tracked in the /_suMNT table. 
Any Task can be converted to a Note by clicking the “Add Note” button next to the Task in the /_suMNT table. 
Notes
A Note is any bit of information that might be useful to our mission or organization. 
All Notes should be entered, categorized, and tracked in the /_suWpE table. 
Any Note can be converted to a Task by clicking the “Add Note” button next to the Note in the /_suWpE table. 
 
Before starting ANY task, make sure it is being tracked in the tasks table. 
When any idea pops into your head that is not a ANY note can
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: Add “Read Receipt” reaction columns to tables with important information
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: Rainy Day in Zimbabwe - working on converting past event information to Coda
values.Description:
I woke up around 5am, left Jess in bed, and worked on the veranda some. When Jess awoke, we shared breakfast and tea over a game of chess. At 8am I taught my first ashtanga yoga class at She of Earth. Then a quick shop at Kava with Jess. Vegetable pies for lunch. 
I worked on the veranda today, listening to a Spotify Radio based on Sufjan Stevens. A rainstorm came and I had to take down all that was on the clothesline. Thankfully it had mostly dried. The day stayed mostly gray. 
Past Events: Today I mostly worked on converting all of our past event details from Google Sheets to Coda /_suZma. This required creating a new /_suQ_M table. 
Metrics: One of the most incredible things about Coda is that all of the different spreadsheets all communicate seamlessly with one another. This made creating a metrics sheet a snap. 
Currency Conversion: Migrating over historical financial information is tricky. In Google Sheets, I used its built-in currency converter to more easily hand calculations. But exchange rates today are very different than they were years ago, so the information is no longer technically accurate. Instead of calculating currency conversion in the spreadsheet, I’ll 
Projects: I also created a new /_suYUt page with all projects that are currently active, on hiatus, complete, or planned for the future. This is now linked in Coda to our /_suWpE and /_suMNT tables.
Press: I also updated the /_suYqS page with a Google search for “Hanoi Philosophy Forum”
Around 2pm I treated myself to a glass of wine. Maybe I’ll have another before the day is through [edit: I did]. 
There has been some tension (just a bit) between me and Jess about my desire to continue working on this project while she wants us to have an easy, relaxed time transitioning to life in Zimbabwe. She has taken me on some excellent adventures to Mana Pools, Nyanga, Mukuvisi, and Ngomakurira. And she doesn’t want me to fret about work right now. 
For better or for worse, so much of my sense of self-worth and identity is tied up in Opening Up. And most of my social network for the last several years has come from these events. I’m pretty socially awkward otherwise. And Jess first met me at a Opening Up event and fell in love with me while I was leading weekly events. I can’t help but think that a part of her attraction to me is based on being the MC at live events. I’ve always considered Opening Up to, in a way, be a bower. 
Now we’re off to a family quiz night!
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
Started working on Opening Up behind the computer at 9am today. 
Last night was Quiz Night at Tin Roof with some more of Jess’ family-friends. We woke up a bit hungover. Cuddled in bed, smashed the NY Times Thursday Crossword (our favorite day) over breakfast, then studied world geography with an app. Kibbles and bone broth for Maxy. Then I did the dishes while listening to a Hidden Brain episode on the evolution of marriage. 
Today’s Plan
Today I’d like to set up a proper public blog Doc on Coda. One that is different from the Doc I’m currently using (which contains many unpolished ideas that aren’t for public eyes). 
Today’s Accomplishments
Well, I did not achieve what I set out to achieve, but I got several things done anyway.
Added a Dashboard: I set up a new Dashboard view in the Team Doc on Coda.io for any team members to see the most important information
Added System for Announcements: I added a view to the dashboard of the Notes table. This shows only entries labeled as Announcements and that have not yet been marked as read by the current logged-in user. 
Active Recurring Tasks: Having a list of recurring tasks to complete every day/week/month/year is really useful. But I realized today that I’ve added many recurring tasks to the list that will be necessary only once a team is formed again and once we have active events. But right now, we don’t 
Cleared Email: I haven’t checked my inbox since the collapse of events in Colorado Springs (and subsequent choice to put all events on hiatus). Today I worked through about 1,200 emails, setting up automatic filters in Gmail.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
In Project Management, there is an important difference between Projects and Tasks. 
A project has a tangible benefit/outcome. Tasks are everything that needs to get done in order to complete the project. 
A Project is something we can be proud of completing and usually take several days/weeks/years to complete in collaboration with multiple people. Projects are usually the product of several completed tasks. As the project advances, new tasks will likely be added (i.e. we learn along the way new things we need to do to complete the project). 
A Useful Distinction
This is a useful/necessary distinction in effective Project Management. Much of Project Management is simply defining what to-dos to focus on, to not overwhelm our staff with too much  because a whole slew of tasks can be eliminated
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
Incest, or sexual relationships between close family members, is a controversial topic, and there are philosophical arguments on both sides of the debate about whether or not it should be criminalized.
One argument in favor of criminalizing incest is that it can be harmful to the individuals involved, both physically and emotionally. Incestuous relationships may be associated with an increased risk of physical harm, such as sexually transmitted infections and unwanted pregnancies, as well as emotional harm, such as feelings of shame, guilt, and isolation. Additionally, some argue that incest is a form of abuse, as it involves a power imbalance between family members and may involve coercion or manipulation.
On the other hand, some argue that criminalizing incest infringes upon the right to personal autonomy and privacy. Some people believe that consenting adults should be able to make their own decisions about their relationships, regardless of whether or not those relationships are considered taboo or socially unacceptable. Some also argue that criminalizing incest disproportionately affects marginalized communities, such as LGBTQ+ individuals, who may face discrimination and persecution for engaging in relationships that are considered "deviant" or "unnatural."
Ultimately, the decision to criminalize incest involves weighing the potential harm that may be caused by such relationships against the right to personal autonomy and privacy. It is a complex and sensitive issue that requires careful consideration of a variety of ethical and moral factors.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
There are both potential health benefits and risks associated with the use of nicotine vape pens.
On the positive side, some research suggests that using nicotine vape pens may be less harmful than smoking cigarettes. This is because e-cigarettes do not produce the same harmful byproducts as cigarettes, such as tar and carbon monoxide. Additionally, nicotine vape pens can provide a way for people to wean themselves off of cigarettes and potentially quit smoking altogether.
However, there are also potential risks associated with the use of nicotine vape pens. Some research has suggested that the chemicals used in e-cigarette liquids may be harmful when inhaled. In addition, nicotine itself is a highly addictive substance, and using nicotine vape pens can lead to dependence and withdrawal symptoms when trying to quit. There have also been reports of serious respiratory issues, including lung injury and death, associated with the use of some e-cigarette products.
It is important to note that the long-term health effects of using nicotine vape pens are not yet fully understood, and more research is needed to fully understand the potential risks and benefits. If you are considering using a nicotine vape pen, it is important to carefully weigh the potential risks and benefits, and to discuss your options with a healthcare professional.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: Mental Health Benefits of Nicotine Vape Pens AI
values.Description:
One potential benefit of using a nicotine vape pen is that it may help people to reduce or quit smoking, which has been linked to a number of mental health problems. Smoking has been associated with an increased risk of anxiety, depression, and other mental health disorders, and quitting smoking may improve mental health.
In addition, some research has suggested that nicotine itself may have some potential mental health benefits. For example, nicotine has been shown to improve memory and cognitive function in some studies, and it may also have some antidepressant and anti-anxiety effects
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: mental health benefits of nicotine cigarettes from not being ostricized
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
There are several logical fallacies that may be committed in arguments for and against eating meat. Some common examples include:
Ad hominem: This fallacy occurs when someone attacks the person making the argument, rather than addressing the argument itself. For example, someone might say “you can’t trust vegans, they’re all preachy and self-righteous” as a way to dismiss an argument made by a vegan.
Straw man: This fallacy occurs when someone misrepresents or exaggerates an opposing argument in order to make it easier to attack. For example, someone might argue that vegans believe that all animal agriculture is inherently wrong, even though this may not be the case.
Appeal to authority: This fallacy occurs when someone appeals to the authority or expertise of someone else as a way to support their argument, without providing any actual evidence. For example, someone might argue that we should eat meat because “experts say it’s healthy,” without providing any actual evidence from experts to support their claim.
Slippery slope: This fallacy occurs when someone suggests that a small change will lead to a series of unintended and undesirable consequences. For example, someone might argue that if we stop eating meat, it will lead to the collapse of the entire agricultural industry.
False dilemma: This fallacy occurs when someone presents two options as if they are the only ones available, when in fact there may be other options. For example, someone might argue that we must either eat meat or starve, when in fact there are many plant-based sources of protein and other nutrients.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: Research Technique: AI Logical Fallacies About Topic
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: Plausibility vs. Probability (just because something could be true, doesn’t mean it is likely true. Just because something could be false or a lie, doesn’t mean it is false or a lie).
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: The unreliability and intentional misreading of statistics

values.Description:
Open the Google Slides file on a Mac
Download the Google Slides file as a .pptx 
Download and run the Copy Keynote Presentation Notes to Clipboard.scpt script (this script exports just the Speaker Notes from presentations opened in Keynote, whether a .key or .pptx)
You will be prompted to select a presentation file. Select the downloaded .pptx file
You will get no notification, but the Speaker Notes are now in your computer’s clipboard. Paste the notes into a new document (likely the Scripts-Only for Video Editing document).
Please note, there is more in Speaker Notes than just a script for presenters. After the Speaker Notes are exported, the next step is to clean them us. Please follow the Technical Guide on Cleaning Up Exported Speaker Notes
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
Keynote is the presentation design software preferred by Real Talk Philosophy, similar to PowerPoint, Prezi, and Google Slides. Although the Keynote app is available only on Apple products, Keynote for iCloud is a browser-based 


Keynote for iCloud Support Guide from Apple
https://support.apple.com/guide/keynote-icloud/intro-to-keynote-for-icloud-gilf2fb004e2/icloud


Browser
It is recommended that you use Google Chrome to access Keynote for iCloud


Sign-in to Keynote for iCloud
Go to www.icloud.com. 
Sign-in to iCloud with your personal iCloud account
Choose Keynote


Request Access to the Appropriate Keynote File
Ask your manager for access to the Keynote file you would like to update. 


Functionality
As of January 2021, the following functions are available in Keynote for iCloud:
Slides
Add new slides
Copy/paste slides
Duplicate slides
Delete slides
Skip (i.e. hide) slides
Add/edit presenter notes
Objects
e.g. text boxes, images, tables
Move objects
Resize objects
Center objects with grid lines
Style
Choose text font, color, size
Underline, bold, and italicize text 
Choose text 
Insert
Add images
Download Slides
Be sure to hide unwanted slides first! 
Download slides as PDF 
Download slides as Keynote file
Download slides as Powerpoint file


Keyboard Shortcuts
https://support.apple.com/guide/keynote-icloud/keyboard-shortcuts-gilf0fb207d1/icloud


Limitations 
The following features are unavailable in Keynote for iCloud:
Editing Master Slides (aka slide templates)
Copy/paste slides from one iCloud for Keynote window/tab into another
Downloading as JPG 


Copy/Paste Slides
Right click a slide and choose Copy
Or press ctrl+c then ctrl+v


Duplicate Slides
Right-click a slide and choose Duplicate


Grid Lines
To help
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy is a social movement and community that is passionate about meaningful discourse, education, and helping reweave the fabric of our hyper-partisan communities.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We're using thought leadership + media + events to explore polarizing issues from all sides.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We want to tear down barriers and bridge social divides with critical thinking, meaningful conversation, artwork, and fun!
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy provides a judgment-free haven for individuals and groups seeking an alternative to conventional conflict-based debate.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: By using the simple but proven tools of facilitated small-group discussion, impartial lectures, artwork analysis, games, and panelist Q&As, we create a space in which anyone can openly discuss divisive issues without fear of being labeled or shamed.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy is a social philosophy collective that hosts events exploring the most polarizing topics of our time and facilitates small group discussions surrounding them, alongside music, art, games, lectures, panelist Q&As, and more.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We promote empathy as an antidote to political polarization.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Politics is inherently divisive, but it doesn’t have to be.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: In a world of dueling soundbites on cable news and posts on social media, we set out to create a space where people can engage with each other thoughtfully—a neutral space for conversation.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy creates community events with a humanist approach to combatting social and political polarization.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Leading with identity rather than ideology, we intentionally seek out "opponents" in our communities in order to better understand each other.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We creating sincere spaces for face-to-face discussions on current affairs and issues relevant to real people, we search for the "fundamental unity of ideas" – broad themes like solidarity, rather than specific ideologies like veganism or anti-fascism, that we can agree upon regardless of our background or self-identification. Our events are enjoyable, enlightening and entertaining, including facilitated small-group discussions, impartial presentations, themed music, art, games, and more.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Our events are OPEN to the public.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: No question is off limits, no statement is too bold, and there's no telling who will show up to engage everyone in a system of diverse viewpoints.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy is an ongoing community that brings people from all walks of life—regardless of identity, opinion, or belief—together in an ongoing discussion about today's challenging issues.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy is a series of events that explore divisive issues in a civil manner to reduce political polarization. We also put on performances, art shows, and social gatherings around these issues.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy creates events that are simultaneously serious and fun, where we can have honest conversation about identity and the convergence of humanism and politics.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We intentionally create conversation with people who hold opposing views to better understand the other side. We search for fundamental themes of unity like solidarity, which we can all agree on, despite our differences.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy is a group that promotes civil discussion of current affairs and societal issues. We put our identity and experiences above our ideology.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: By intentionally creating an open forum for people with differing points of view, we are able to find common ground. By doing so, we aim to create a community based on unity rather than divisiveness.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy hosts events that encourage honest dialogues about identity and the convergence of humanism and politics. We connect with people who hold opposing views to better understand one another while tackling the difficult issues of our time. Facing these challenges together allows us to find common ground and stand with each other in solidarity.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy creates events to help people engage in dialogue. We create a space for people to share their stories and strengthen their relationships across differences.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We create events where people discuss serious and important topics but we do it with a twist. We have fun. We savor food and drink. And we talk about views that may be different from our own in a safe space where everyone is welcome.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy is a series of events that expose people to all sides of divisive issues in an evidence-based, entertaining and thoughtful way, and facilitate genuine cross-community dialogue. We do this through small group discussions and impartial experts whose goal is not to persuade you but rather share their knowledge so you can make up your own mind. These are just some of the many features we offer:
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy creates community with moderated, small group discussions on meaningful issues, while also encouraging participants (from all sides of the issue) to have fun and share a meal together. We're a social club for anyone who wants to join us in actively combating political polarization. We use food, art, games, and music to get people up close and personal, creating a setting where people often discover they actually have a lot in common.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Through Real Talk Philosophy, we bring people with diverse beliefs and backgrounds together to build meaningful, respectful relationships, and mend our fractured society. We do this via community events where we discuss all sides of divisive issues. These events take place in a welcoming setting for participants to engage each other on topics they would otherwise avoid. We also welcome speakers with conflicting views to further advance dialogue and understanding. With love above all else, let's address the challenges we face in today's world together.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: You may leave inspired, infuriated, intrigued, amused--but one thing is certain: you won't be the same person as when you came in.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Let’s talk about it.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Truth over Ideology. Understanding over Debate. Cooperation over Conflict.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We believe in the power of facilitating conversations with the goal of thorough understanding, opening minds, instilling hope, and coming out the other side with real friendships.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We use art and conversation to deconstruct barriers.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We use art and conversation to break down the barriers that keep people from connecting with each other.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy is a forum for free speech and independent thinking. It’s a place to discuss the things that matter – without the ideological baggage.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Our mission is to depolarize communities, countries, and perhaps even the world one conversation at a time.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real Talk Philosophy aims to gather people together across lines of questioning that have historically divided them.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We are committed to creating real connections and fostering honest communication, especially in today's increasingly divided political climate.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We can disagree without being disagreeable.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: At Real Talk Philosophy, we inspire people to think critically and question the world around them in a safe, unintimidating space.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We engage in honest dialogue that discusses the relevant questions and concerns of our day. We need this conversation now more than ever.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: When we put our differences aside, speak our minds, and listen to one another's stories, we can begin to create mutual understanding and bridge the divides
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Through the shared experience of difference, we can cultivate a greater empathy for all people, and together we can create social change that leaves no one behind.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Difference is not a threat, but an opportunity for learning and growth. By respecting difference, we make room for new ideas and ways to do things, and in turn, we create better spaces and communities.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We believe that by having uncomfortable conversations with friends and family, we can cultivate a culture of inclusiveness. By listening to different perspectives, we can break barriers and make the world a better place.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Bridges not walls.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: What if it's not us vs. them?
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Join us for an evening of stimulating discussion and fun in our ongoing efforts to overcome the growing social ills that keep humanity divided.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Our goal is to usher in a new era of respectful, measured discourse that leads to genuine understanding and - even more importantly - meaningful connections.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We're against hate, not ideas.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We Come Together To Talk It Out
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Transcending polarization. Creating meaningful community.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We use art and conversation to create spaces for dialogue about issues that matter.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: inspires happiness and sanity through serious talks on hot topics
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: RTP. Creating the kind of conversations that are needed now.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: By the end of this experience, you will have better internalized more generous and thoughtful perspectives from both "sides"
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Real talk deals with the issues that matter. The kind of conversations that don’t happen enough around the dinner table. In print and on stage.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We create spaces of inclusion, thoughtfulness, and productive dialogue.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Community and conversation are the best antidotes for division and fear.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Creating a more inclusive and understanding society one conversation at a time.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We believe that less bias and more dialogue leads to a better understanding of the world around us, which ultimately leads to a better society.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Collectively, we are building a community that can disagree productively and come to peaceful resolutions.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Helping people explore their most deeply held values and overcome ideological rigidity through deep conversation.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Helping people identify underlying values and overcome ideology through friendly conversation that is both open-minded and empathetic.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We believe that deep conversation can spark progress, so we create spaces for that to happen.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Part community center, part social club, this grassroots collective...
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: The most effective way to combat social and political polarization is to create the conditions for people to get real and honest about the beliefs that they hold close to
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: Let's talk about it. Join us as we use art and conversation to deconstruct barriers.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We make it easier to understand the world around you by sharing intelligence and experiences.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: Response to an Unknown Scheduled Meeting
values.Description:
Dear Name, 
Thank you for booking a time to meet with me on Calendly. I do not see any emails, Facebook messages, or website form submissions including your name or email address. Have you contacted us in the past? Were you perhaps using a different name email address? What is this meeting concerning? 
Thanks so much! 
Name
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
Dear Name,
On Date, Chapter Name will be hosting an event exploring debates around Topic. As a part of this event, we will be playing a card game. Could you please print the attached game cards, cut them, arrange them, and send them to our Local Chapter Leader in Colorado Springs, Shahin Kaveh?
PDF
Game Cards PDF: URL to Game Cards PDF, for examplehttps://drive.google.com/file/d/1wp-aYqoiGMHuJ0eibeLzLG_LpGGgd3Hs/view?usp=sharing
Specific Instructions
The goal is to have 9 decks of 25 unique cards. The PDF is 25 pages long. Each page has 9 copies of the same card. 
Please print 1 copy of link to the PDF (# pages) on 200-400 gsm paper (whichever weight in this range is least expensive). The back of the cards can remain white. 
Please cut out the individual cards (9 x 25 = 225 cards in total)
Please arrange the cards into 9 decks of 25 unique cards, fastened with rubberbands or similar. 
Please deliver the package of 9 decks of 25 cards each to Name at Address, to receive on or before Date. 
Scrap Paper
Also, do you have any scrap paper (with at least 1 side blank) that we could use at our event?
Please let me know if you have any questions. My phone number is xxx-xxx-xxxx
Best,
Name
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
Hey! This is Jon and I’d like to quickly update everyone on what we are working on at Real Talk Philosophy. 
This is my home. And this is where most of the action takes place day to day. 
We have a big team spread out all over the world in the US, the UK, Vietnam, Thailand, Singapore, Indonesia. But here, it’s just me. 
Suthaphat was able to come over for a bit today; that was nice. 
So, at the time of recording, 6 July 2021, we have had 229 events in 8 cities for 8,292 guests. But, all of our chapters are currently shut down due to Coronavirus. 
That hasn’t stopped us though. We are still working on a lot here at Real Talk! 
Chiang Mai: We are prepping for our first event in Chiang Mai, Thailand since December, which will be happening this Thursday. 
Online: We have also been working to move the in-person experience online. 
We’ve recorded and edited lecture videos for several topics including psychedelics, polyamory, the origins of sexual orientation, the ethics of comedy, and the psychological differences between easterners and westerners. 
We’ve also been creating online games and quizzes for guests to play during our online events. 
And we’ve been working with the developers at Junto to help create our first automated online events 
Presentations: We’ve been migrating all of our most popular presentations from Keynote, which is Mac’s version of Powerpoint, to Google Slides so more people can collaborate and to integrate more easily with other systems. 
And updating our presentations with legal, licensed images from our partners at Envato Elements
USA: We’ve also been preparing for our expansion to the United States 
Applying to accelerators and incubators/ 
Applying to pitch to Investors, which is challenging from abroad. 
Applying to post on university job boards looking for Local Chapter Leaders 
Research: Our Research Team has continued to create new content for future explorations
Website: We’ve been updating our website, giving anyone access to all of our research for free, hopefully as a way to spread the word about our online and in-person events events. 
Admin: We’ve been revamping the way our team tracks their hours and communicates their progress 
EFL: Developing our EFL (English as a Foreign Language) program
Creating vocabulary sheets
Creating course completion certificates 
Hosted demo lessons 
Created marketing materials
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
Summary
Before hosting full events (i.e. events with music, artwork, etc.), LCLs are asked to first host regularly scheduled, free, MVP events in parks, libraries, etc. until their regular attendance reaches at least 25 non-staff guests. It is 100% our hope that these events will ”graduate” to full Opening Up Philosophy Events. 
“Dream big; start small.” 

What are “MVP” Events? 
MVP stands for Minimum Viable Product. What is required at minimum to produce a Opening Up event? 
A host 
Guests
A topic
Discussion Questions
MVP Events do not (i.e. needn’t necessarily) offer experts, music, artwork, presentations, haiku/drawing contests, games, etc. As events progress, the inclusion of additional Event Elements is encouraged, but not required. 
MVP events are offered for free/donation. As such, we try to elliminate event costs (e.g. advertising, paid-venues, etc.).  
Rationale
Asking LCLs to host free MVP events before hosting full Opening Up Events has many benefits. 
Accelerated Onboarding: Rather than asking LCLs to complete a months-long onboarding process peraring for rather complex events (including music, games, etc.), LCLs can instead begin hosting MVP events within a number of weeks.
Host Practice: Hosting MVP Events will allow LCLs the opportunity to practice facilitating divisive issue conversations. They will grow an understanding of the art of discussion facilitation without concern for all the other bells and whistles. 
Gradual Event Complexity Build: Ideally, the events will grow increasingly, incrementally complex over time. Additional Event Elements (e.g. music, artwork) will be added slowly according to the LCL’s comfort. 
Gradual Team Build: Hosting MVP Events will allow potential collaborators (e.g. visual artists, musicians, volunteers, etc.) to sign-up, join the local team, and understand the intention and “vibe” of our events. 
Gradual Community Build: Hosting free MVP events will allow the local community to grow familiar with our events and ensure that these events are even wanted. Hosting free events will also allow some to join and build the community who may not be able to join once the events are not free. 
LCL Empowerment: Expecting new LCLs to begin hosting full RTP events requires a lot of specific direction and decision-making from the Central Team, decreasing LCL involvement in top-level decision making for the chapter. This accelerated MVP system will allow local chapters to develop slowly, organicaly, allowing LCLs to understand more fully the events, event responsibilities, and their audience, before launching into full RTP events. 
Decreased Central Responsibility: Much of the Central Team’s responsibility has been putting out fires caused by expecting LCLs to host full RTP events too quickly. This accelerated MVP system will decrease the need for Central involvement 
Decreased Central Financial Exposure: Gauranteeing LCL salaries comes at a great financial risk for the Central Team. 
Provided Resources
Topical Google Slides Presentation
The intention of providing the Topical Google Slides Presentation is not for LCLs to present the presentation (this only occurs once the event is 
Hosting Outline & Suggested Scripts
Discussion Questions
Healthy Conversation Guidelines
Agenda of MVP Events
Pre-Requisites
Post an event online 
Explore and attempt to fully understand the arguments on both sides of the topic/issue
Print discussion questions, healthy conversation, necessary announcements, and email and team signup forms
Setup
The LCL sets up the space to be comfortable and inviting (e..g with signs, blankets, pillows, tea, etc.) 
The LCL sets up the email and team signup forms
Guest Arrival & Individual Welcomes: Guests arrive at the space. They don’t know exactly where to go, who to talk to, etc. As guests arrive, the host welcomes them individually, hands them conversation guidelines and questions, and leads them to join small-group discussion groups. 
Small-Group Discussion Questions #1: Guests are invited to form groups of 3-5 to explore pre-devised questions related to the topic.
Summary of Both Sides: The host will speak for 5-10 minutes ad hoc exploring the major arguments on each side of the topic. 
Small-Group Discussion Questions #2: Guests are invited to form NEW groups of 3-5 to explore pre-devised questions related to the topic.
After Party: Guests are invited to stay and continue conversing in a less structured context. 
Possible Free Locations
Park
Library
Beach
Cafe
Bar
Restaurant
Recreation Center
Script

values.Description: We create safe spaces for free expression of ideas. By suspending judgment, we allow for the exploration of diverse thoughts without fear of ridicule or discrimination.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We nurture a spirit of inquiry and continuous learning. By encouraging questions and exploration, we foster an environment where intellectual growth flourishes.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We encourage an open-minded approach to different perspectives. Recognizing our own limitations and striving to understand others' viewpoints are key to productive dialogue and personal growth.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We foster environments where diverse individuals connect through meaningful dialogue. Our events transform strangers into collaborators, creating a network of engaged thinkers.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
We actively work to create a representative community. By bringing together individuals from various backgrounds, we enrich our discussions and broaden our collective understanding.
This includes promoting diversity in terms of race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, age, ability, religion, and socio-economic status, and more.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We present multiple perspectives fairly and objectively, without allowing personal biases to influence the presentation of information. Our role is to illuminate various viewpoints, allowing participants to form their own informed opinions. Our should never be used as a pulpit for any one person’s ideas, opinions, or beliefs.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We commit to open and honest communication. By sharing information freely and trusting our audience with complex ideas, we build credibility and foster deeper engagement.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We pay careful attention to every aspect of our events. Through thorough planning and execution, we create polished, professional experiences that respect our participants' time and engagement.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We recognize the role of aesthetics in enhancing intellectual experiences. By creating visually appealing and engaging events, we stimulate both mind and senses.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We leverage collective wisdom to address complex issues. By fostering teamwork and idea-sharing, we tap into the diverse expertise of our community.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We embrace a growth mindset, viewing challenges as opportunities for learning and innovation. By consistently refining our approach, we ensure our practices evolve with our community's needs.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description: We incorporate environmentally responsible practices into our operations. By considering our ecological impact, we ensure our pursuit of wisdom doesn't come at the cost of our planet's health.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
“What’s in a name?” For us, quite a lot. The name of our organization is a moniker that rencompasses all of our countless guests, events, staff, contributors, content, resources, songs, artwork, games, etc. Our name is the very first thing people hear about us and our #1 marketing tool. 
The Hanoi Philosophy Forum
We began in March 2017 as The Hanoi Philosophy Forum. Back then, we were little more than a philosophy book club, exploring books like Nietzsche’s Beyond Good and Evil, Foucault’s The History of Madness, or Kierkegaard’s Fear and Trembling. We were located in Hanoi; we read philosophy; and we weren’t just lecture-based but a forum. The name was clear and direct (and easily understood by non-native english speakers). 
By September 2018, it became clear that our attendees came because they were desperate for a space to candidly talk about important issues, not just academic philosophy. Our focus shifted away from academic philosophy and towards divisive social issues (e.g. polyamory, toxic masculinity, veganism, etc). Also around this time, to make the events more entertaining and appealing, we started incorporating themed artwork, music, and games. We wanted these events to be accessible to all, but “philosophy” conjured up images of old, white men smoking pipes debating the definition of dialectical materialism. The term “philosophy” was intimidating, cumbersome, and no longer a good match for us. 
We started brainstorming hundreds of potential new names (e.g. The Other Side, The Depolarization Project, Likewise), but every time we fell in love with one, we discovered to our chagrin that the URL was already taken or a Facebook page already existed. So, despite the name:vision mismatch, HPF persisted. 
Real Talk Philosophy
In 2020 we began expanding operations internationally from Vietnam to Thailand, Singapore, Indonesia, and the US. A new name, one unlinked from any particular locale, was necessary. Through a series of intense discussions with our most loyal members, we voted for the name Real Talk Philosophy (#2 was Nomad Philosophy Forum). 
Adopting a new name is no easy task. In addition to updating website URLs, Social Media handles, logos, marketing materials, and website content; changing the name of an organization requires the consideration of legal registrations, financial account information, and trademarks. Also, we lose some familiarity and street-cred each time we switch to a new name. 
Urban Dictionary defines Real Talk as “The philosophy of talking candidly and openly and honestly without fear of what others might think” and “usually for another's benefit to let them know of something that is typically hard to discuss.” This is a 100% match for the kind of space we want to create. Real Talk easily rolls off the tongue; it’s colloquial, memorable, and easy to type. Real Talk highlights that we are discussion-based, and juxtaposes well against our arch-nemesis, the reviled “small talk.” 
But, unfortunately, we found that Real Talk is also ubiquitous, trite almost (just search for podcasts, articles, apps, magazines, school newspaper columns, etc. sharing this name). And where tried were to attempt to overcome this by tacking on “Philosophy,” the name became unnecessarily cumbersome, too difficult to type, and too long to put on an event poster. It’s also a bit arrogant. ‘Forget about that silly fake talk they’re having over there; here we have REAL talk!’ 
Opening Up
In early 2022, the prolonged COVID rules on public gatherings forced us to make the difficult decision to put all chapters on indefinite hiatus. I was, for the first time in 5 years, able to take a break, a step back, a rest. 
While reading Michael Singer’s The Untethered Soul, a single phrase kept reappearing and concretizing in my mind - “open up.” One bit of Michael’s advice that I found poignant: whenever your mind is stuck on some problem, some persistent negative thought, whenever the world feels like it is collapsing, rather than try to push the thought away, simply practice “opening up.” Open up to all the sounds and sights in the space around you; to any smells, tastes, or physical sensations. Open up to everything you have to be grateful for.
Opening up means to explore, inspect, and dissect with curiosity. It means to speak vulnerably, honestly, and emotionally. Opening up means to release a covering, to allow things to more easily flow in and flow out. It refers to starting a new novel, a new adventure; to being a novice, not an expert. In a game of billiards, Opening Up means to clear the table so the good game can begin, without all the rubbish getting in the way.
And best of all, the .org was available for purchase! This final step of adopting a new name has so often undermined us in the past.

values.Summary: Timeline of the domestication of dogs
values.Description:
The domestication of dogs is a complex process that likely occurred over thousands of years, and the exact timeline is still a subject of ongoing research. However, some key milestones in the evolution of dogs include:
20,000-30,000 years ago: Early human societies begin to settle down and form communities, leading to the formation of a symbiotic relationship between humans and wolves. Wolves that were more tolerant of human presence were more likely to survive and reproduce, and as a result, their offspring became increasingly domesticated.
15,000-20,000 years ago: Dogs have evolved to the point where they are visibly different from wolves, and have developed a number of traits that are associated with domestication, such as smaller teeth and jaws, shorter snouts, and rounder skulls.
10,000-15,000 years ago: Humans begin to selectively breed dogs for specific traits, such as hunting ability, herding ability, or guarding ability. This leads to the development of different breeds of dogs, each with their own set of characteristics and abilities.
5,000-10,000 years ago: The earliest known dog breeds, such as the Saluki, the Basenji, and the Afghan Hound, are believed to have emerged around this time. These breeds were likely developed for specific hunting or herding tasks.
2,000-5,000 years ago: The ancient Egyptians and Greeks begin to breed dogs for specific purposes, such as hunting and guarding. This leads to the development of a number of new breeds, including the Mastiff, the Greyhound, and the Spitz.
1,000 years ago: Many of the breeds that we know today begin to emerge, such as the Poodle, the Labrador Retriever, and the Bulldog. These breeds were likely developed for specific tasks such as retrieving game, herding livestock, and guarding property.
It’s worth noting that this is a very rough timeline and that various researchers may have different opinions and details on the exact timing and development of different breeds.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: Timeline of the evolution of domestic cats
values.Description:
The domestication of cats is a less well-understood process than the domestication of dogs, but some key milestones in the evolution of domestic cats include:
10,000-12,000 years ago: The domestication of cats is believed to have begun around this time, as early human settlements began to accumulate large amounts of grain and other foodstuffs, which attracted wild felines (proto-domestic cats) that preyed on the rodents that were attracted to the stored food.
8,000-10,000 years ago: The first evidence of cats living in close association with humans is found in the Near East.
4,000-5,000 years ago: Cats were domesticated by the ancient Egyptians, who valued them for their ability to control rodents.
2,000-3,000 years ago: Cats were spread throughout the Mediterranean by Roman traders and merchants, and were valued for their hunting abilities.
1,000 years ago: The earliest known cat breeds, such as the Siamese and the Persian, are believed to have emerged around this time. These breeds were likely developed for specific aesthetic or behavioral characteristics.
It’s worth noting that the timeline for cat domestication is less clear and less studied than that of dogs, and some researchers have argued that cats were never fully domesticated and have instead adopted a symbiotic relationship with humans. Also, as with the dog timeline, different researchers may have different opinions on the exact timing and development of different breeds.

values.Description:
*Venue Recommendations?*
Hello lovely humans! @realtalkphilosophy is opening a new chapter in city. Which venues would be best to host us?
*Venue Requirements*
Projection screen/TV
Microphone and PA System
Seating for 30-60 people arranged so that everyone can see the screen and breakout into small-group discussions
Drink and Food menu with veggie options
Chapter Name will host weekly events exploring divisive social issues - from polyamory to antinatalism - with discussions, lectures, music, games, artwork, and more. For more information, visit www.openingup.org or watch our Explainer Video at https://youtu.be/RNpl2oWi3ug
Screen Shot 2564-10-22 at 13.02.48.png
Be sure to tag Opening Up Philosophy, your Local Opening Up Facebook Group and to include photos of past events in your post so potential venues can get a sense of the energy and crowd-size of an Opening Up event.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Summary: First Email to a Potential Venue
values.Description:
Dear Name,
Thank you for all the work you do hosting community events in city! Would you be interested in hosting a new weekly event? 
Chapter Name is looking for a new home to host our weekly events, each with music, artwork, games, presentations, community conversations, and more.
Since 2017 Opening Up has hosted more than 200 community events exploring contemporary, divisive issues (like polyamory, psychedelics, feminism, conspiracy theories, fetishes, etc.) with guided small-group discussions, unbiased talks, themed music, artwork, games, and more. Events in Da Nang, Hanoi, and Chiang Mai range from 40-130 guests per event. See our explainer video at www.youtu.be/RNpl2oWi3ug or find out more at www.openingup.org. 
Our events are 2.5 hours long, and are scheduled for eating hours, so most people order food and several drinks. This is an excellent opportunity for venues to find more customers. 
Our events require a projector and screen (or large television), microphone and speakers, and seating for 30-40+ people. Could your venue accommodate? 
We would like to host our first event in city on date. Once you and I confirm, my team will begin advertising. 
Thanks so much!
Name
Of course, spicing up the email with more local, colloquial jargon is invited.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
Dear Name,
Thank you for expressing interest in becoming a Local Chapter Leader with Real Talk Philosophy!
Could you please send your CV/resume and cover letter to us on Facebook @realtalkphilosophy or to admin@realtalkphilosophy.org?
Looking forward to hearing from you soon,
Name

values.Description:
In conversations around divisive social issues, the word “should” can come up a lot. For example, you might hear “The government should pay for tertiary education” or “you should be able to stomach killing an animal if you’re willing to eat meat.” 
But what does the word “should” mean? 
In conversations where we want our beliefs to be understood by others (and hopefully learn something about ourselves through the process), it can be really beneficial to 
The word “should” is lazy. What I mean is, the word “should” can be used in a variety of circumstances where it would be beneficial for someone to do something. But “should” is unspecific as to what that benefit might be (or what detriment it might be shielding us from). And identifying the specific benefits and detriments is exactly what’s necessary when attempting to inform someone of what we believe. And it is the only way to understand in ourselves why we believe what we believe. 
Please include information about the etymology of the word “should” and if it ever had moral/religious connotations. 
Please include any other topics that would be relatively on-topic and/or entertaining
Use a friendly, playful, humble, philosophical tone
Please add examples
Please define any jargon
Please include any studies or scholastic work that have been written on the subject

—
AI Generated:
The Pitfalls of Using the Word "Should"
Introduction
The word "should" is often used in conversations to express a belief or expectation about what someone else ought to do or think. For example, you might hear someone say, "You should be more concerned about immigrants at the border" or "You should be able to stomach killing an animal if you're willing to eat meat." While the word "should" can be a useful tool for expressing our beliefs, it can also be problematic as it tends to be unspecific and may not adequately explain the reasons behind a particular belief or policy. This can lead to misunderstandings, miscommunication, and even conflict.
In this guide, we will explore the problems with using the word "should" in conversations, and offer strategies for promoting healthier and more productive dialogues. 
The Meaning of "Should"
"Should" is a modal verb that is used to express obligation, expectation, or advisability. It is derived from the Old English word "sceolde," which means "obligation" or "duty." 
Interestingly, "should" is a past tense form of the word "shall," which originally meant "owe" or "be under obligation." "Shall" and "should" were once interchangeable, with "shall" used for first person subjects (I, we) and "should" used for second and third person subjects (you, he/she/it/they). However, over time, "shall" became more associated with expressing a future intention, while "should" retained its obligation or expectation connotations.
In the past, “should” was used to talk about what was expected of someone based on religious beliefs. Today, "should" has evolved to have a more general meaning, and it is often used to express opinions or recommendations without necessarily invoking any specific moral or religious code.
The Pitfalls of Using "Should"
The word "should" can be problematic when used in conversations, as it can be vague and unspecific. For example, saying "You should recycle more" doesn't really explain why you believe that or how it would benefit the environment. Additionally, using "should" can come across as prescriptive or judgmental, which can put the listener on the defensive and make them less likely to engage in a productive conversation.
Strategies for Promoting Healthier Conversations
Instead of using "should," it is more effective to use specific and descriptive language that explains the benefits and drawbacks of a particular action or belief. For example, instead of saying "You should go vegan," you might explain the health benefits of a plant-based diet or the environmental impact of animal agriculture. Additionally, using open-ended questions and active listening can help promote healthier and more productive conversations. By asking questions that invite different perspectives and listening actively to what others have to say, we can foster a more inclusive and collaborative dialogue.
Conclusion
In conclusion, using the word "should" in conversations can be problematic as it tends to be unspecific and may not adequately explain the reasons behind a particular belief or policy. Instead, using descriptive language and open-ended questions can help promote healthier and more productive conversations, even on divisive issues. By explaining the benefits and drawbacks of a particular belief or policy, we can encourage a more informed and respectful dialogue, and find common ground with others who may have different perspectives.
values.Author: Jon Dallas

values.Description:
Academic style
[Writing style guideline: Use a formal and academic tone paired with sophisticated vocabulary and grammar. Provide a thorough and in-depth analysis of the subject matter. Explain complex scientific concepts in a clear and accessible way. Use examples from a variety of fields, such as psychology and cognitive science. Present counter-arguments and dissenting opinions in a balanced and objective way.]
How to define yearly goals effectively?
Executive-level summary
Executive-level summary — it is similar to the 5th grader style (YIKES), but here we are asking to make the information as “dense” as possible.
Identify in writing style guidelines the specific response requested
[Writing style guidelines: Return only the category]
I want you to act as a personal assistant. I will provide you with categories and I want you to respond with the best one. My first request is "Identify which category is most closely related to the stance: The 'Bro Code' promotes harmless male bonding." 
Categories: 
- Toxic masculinity is a harmful societal construct that perpetuates negative behaviors and reinforces gender inequality.
- Toxic masculinity unfairly demonizes men and ignores positive aspects of masculinity.
- Toxic masculinity and toxic femininity are both harmful and need to be addressed to promote healthy forms of masculinity and femininity.
- The focus on toxic masculinity detracts from more important issues facing society and is used to promote an agenda.

Templates
Write a five multiple-choice questions on U.S. History. Please use the format template. Do not repeat answers.
---BEGIN FORMAT TEMPLATE---
${QUESTION}
A) ${ANSWER 1}
B) ${ANSWER 2}
C) ${ANSWER 3}
D) ${ANSWER 4}
Correct Answer: ${CHOICE A, B, C, or D}
---END FORMAT TEMPLATE---
---BEGIN QUESTIONS---
